Let $f(n)\to \infty$ as $n\to \infty$. Is it true that\[\sum_{n\geq 1} \frac{1}{(n+1)\cdots (n+f(n))}\]is irrational?



Erd\H{o}s and Graham write 'the answer is almost surely in the affirmative if $f(n)$ is assumed to be nondecreasing'. Even the case $f(n)=n$ is unknown, although Hansen \cite{Ha75} has shown that\[\sum_n \frac{1}{\binom{2n}{n}}=\sum_n \frac{n!}{(n+1)\cdots (n+n)}=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{2\pi}{3^{5/2}}\]is transcendental.

Crmari\'{c} and Kova\v{c} \cite{CrKo25} have shown that the answer to this question is no in a strong sense: for any $\alpha \in (0,\infty)$ there exists a function $f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N}$ such that $f(n)\to \infty$ as $n\to\infty$ and\[\sum_{n\geq 1} \frac{1}{(n+1)\cdots (n+f(n))}=\alpha.\]It is still possible that this sum is always irrational if $f$ is assumed to be non-decreasing; Crmari\'{c} and Kova\v{c} show that the set of the possible values of such a sum has Lebesgue measure zero.





References


[CrKo25] T. Crmari\'{c} and V. Kova\v{c}, On the irrationality of certain super-polynomially decaying series. arXiv:2504.18712 (2025).

[Ha75] Hansen, E. R., A Table of Series and Products. Prentice-Hall (1975), 87.
